TITLESTMT.DOCTITLE: Autumn 1834: Charles Babbage envisioned the Analytical...

FILEDESC.SOURCEDESC: Created from original research by members of the Orlando Project

RESPONSIBILITY.ITEM: BATCH CHANGE: primarily orgName and bibCit cleanup
added IBM and Ada language info

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Charles Babbage envisioned the Analytical Engine or calculating machine, an advance on his previous work on the Difference Engine and precursor to the modern computer.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Using punch cards, the Analytical Engine he designed could carry out any combination of arithmetic operations and algebraic functions. Although he was hampered by lack of funding to build his elaborate invention, as well as the fact that the precision milling and machinery necessary for some of its parts simply did not yet exist,
633 Babbage continued to refine and modify his ideas of the Analytical Engine until his death in 1871. On the strength of her analysis of its potential applications, Augusta Ada Byron has been hailed as the first computer programmer. Using Babbage's plans and current machining technology, IBM recently constructed the Analytical Engine.

RESEARCHNOTES.RESEARCHNOTE: sib: needs to be merged with info on analytical engine from shortprose to info on difference engine ch1829-e; related event also in vicsci-e: links needed
